title: 2 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 5.

questions.question: Who was Naaman according to 2 Kings 5:1?
options: Captain of the host of the king of Syria
King of Israel
A prophet in Samaria
A servant of Elisha
questions.correctAnswer: Captain of the host of the king of Syria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:1 states that Naaman was the captain of the host of the king of Syria.

questions.question: What disease did Naaman suffer from in 2 Kings 5:1?
options: Leprosy
Blindness
Paralysis
Fever
questions.correctAnswer: Leprosy
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:1 clearly mentions that Naaman was a leper.

questions.question: From where was the little maid who served Naaman's wife taken captive? (2 Kings 5:2)
options: The land of Israel
The land of Egypt
The land of Babylon
The land of Moab
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:2 states that the little maid was brought captive out of the land of Israel.

questions.question: What did the little maid suggest to Naaman's wife about healing Naaman's leprosy? (2 Kings 5:3)
options: He should go to the prophet in Samaria
He should go to the rivers of Damascus
He should seek the king of Syria
He should pray alone
questions.correctAnswer: He should go to the prophet in Samaria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:3 says the maid told her mistress that if her lord were with the prophet in Samaria, he would recover him of his leprosy.

questions.question: What did the king of Syria send to the king of Israel along with Naaman? (2 Kings 5:5)
options: Ten talents of silver, six thousand pieces of gold, and ten changes of raiment
Ten horses and chariots
A letter only
A gift of olive oil and wine
questions.correctAnswer: Ten talents of silver, six thousand pieces of gold, and ten changes of raiment
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:5 details the gifts Naaman took with him: ten talents of silver, six thousand pieces of gold, and ten changes of raiment.

questions.question: How did the king of Israel react when he read the letter from the king of Syria? (2 Kings 5:7)
options: He rent his clothes and said he was not God
He welcomed Naaman immediately
He sent soldiers to capture Naaman
He ignored the letter
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his clothes and said he was not God
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:7 describes how the king of Israel rent his clothes and said he was not God to kill or make alive.

questions.question: What instruction did Elisha send to Naaman for his healing? (2 Kings 5:10)
options: Go and wash in Jordan seven times
Offer a sacrifice at the temple
Pray seven times daily
Anoint himself with oil
questions.correctAnswer: Go and wash in Jordan seven times
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:10 states Elisha sent a message telling Naaman to wash in the Jordan seven times to be clean.

questions.question: Why was Naaman angry after hearing Elisha's instructions? (2 Kings 5:11)
options: He expected Elisha to come out and perform a ritual
He did not believe Elisha was a prophet
He wanted to pay Elisha immediately
He thought the rivers of Damascus were better
questions.correctAnswer: He expected Elisha to come out and perform a ritual
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:11 says Naaman was wroth because he thought Elisha would come out, call on the LORD, and strike over the place to heal him.

questions.question: What rivers did Naaman compare to the waters of Israel? (2 Kings 5:12)
options: Abana and Pharpar
Jordan and Euphrates
Tigris and Nile
Gihon and Pishon
questions.correctAnswer: Abana and Pharpar
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:12 records Naaman asking if he could wash in Abana and Pharpar, rivers of Damascus, which he thought better than Israel's waters.

questions.question: Did Naaman eventually obey Elisha's instruction and wash in the Jordan? (2 Kings 5:14)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:14 states that Naaman dipped himself seven times in the Jordan as Elisha had said and was healed.

questions.question: What did Naaman declare after being healed? (2 Kings 5:15)
options: There is no God in all the earth but in Israel
He would return to Syria and forget Israel
He would become a prophet
He would seek more healing
questions.correctAnswer: There is no God in all the earth but in Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:15 records Naaman saying he now knew there was no God in all the earth except in Israel.

questions.question: Did Elisha accept a gift from Naaman? (2 Kings 5:16)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:16 explains that Elisha refused to receive any gift from Naaman.

questions.question: What did Naaman request to take with him to Syria for worship purposes? (2 Kings 5:17)
options: Two mules' burden of earth
A gold idol
A scroll of the law
A jar of oil
questions.correctAnswer: Two mules' burden of earth
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:17 states Naaman asked for two mules' burden of earth to offer sacrifices to the LORD in Syria.

questions.question: Naaman asked for pardon from the LORD because he would have to bow in the house of Rimmon. (2 Kings 5:18)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:18 shows Naaman asking for forgiveness when he bows in the house of Rimmon as part of serving his master.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from 2 Kings 5:21: 'When Naaman saw Gehazi running after him, he __________ from the chariot to meet him.'
options: lighted down
rode faster
called out
hid himself
questions.correctAnswer: lighted down
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:21 states Naaman lighted down from the chariot to meet Gehazi when he saw him running after him.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Naaman's initial reaction to Elisha's instructions teach us about humility and obedience in trials?
options: He immediately obeyed without question
He was angry and resistant to simple obedience
He prayed for more signs before obeying
He sought advice from other prophets first
questions.correctAnswer: He was angry and resistant to simple obedience
questions.explanation: Naaman was wroth and angry because he expected a grand gesture, not simple washing in the Jordan (2 Kings 5:11-12). This shows the challenge of humility and trusting God's instructions even when they seem simple or unimpressive. The passage teaches us that obedience often requires humility and trust (2 Kings 5:10, 13-14).

questions.question: What biblical truth about faith and healing can be learned from Naaman dipping seven times in the Jordan River?
options: Faith requires specific obedience even in small things
Healing comes only through elaborate rituals
Faith is shown by demanding immediate results
Obedience is optional if you believe
questions.correctAnswer: Faith requires specific obedience even in small things
questions.explanation: Naaman's healing came only after he obeyed the prophet's instruction to dip seven times in the Jordan (2 Kings 5:14). This teaches that faith involves trusting God's word and obeying instructions fully, even when they seem insignificant (2 Kings 5:10, 13, 14).

questions.question: How does the role of the Israelite captive maid in Naaman's story encourage us about influence and witnessing in family life?
options: Her testimony was ignored by Naaman
Her faith led to a miracle for Naaman
She returned to Israel immediately
She discouraged Naaman from seeking healing
questions.correctAnswer: Her faith led to a miracle for Naaman
questions.explanation: The maid from Israel encouraged Naaman's wife to seek the prophet's help (2 Kings 5:2-3). Her quiet faith and witness in the household led to Naaman's healing, showing how godly influence within family can lead to spiritual breakthroughs (2 Kings 5:1-3, 14-15).

questions.question: What does Elisha's refusal of Naaman's gift teach us about integrity and stewardship in Christian service?
options: God's servants can accept gifts freely
Elisha accepted the gift to show gratitude
Elisha refused to keep integrity pure
Elisha refused to accept gifts to maintain honesty
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha refused to accept gifts to maintain honesty
questions.explanation: Elisha refused Naaman's gifts, emphasizing that God's blessings and healing are not for sale (2 Kings 5:15-16). This teaches that Christian workers should serve with integrity and not be motivated by personal gain (2 Kings 5:15-17).

questions.question: How does Naaman's request for two mule burdens of earth reflect the importance of spiritual discipline and worship?
options: He wanted to worship multiple gods freely
He desired to maintain worship of the LORD in a foreign land
He planned to build a temple in Syria
He rejected all forms of worship
questions.correctAnswer: He desired to maintain worship of the LORD in a foreign land
questions.explanation: Naaman asked for earth to offer sacrifices to the LORD, showing his commitment to worship God even while living in a land with other gods (2 Kings 5:17). This illustrates the importance of personal devotion and spiritual discipline regardless of circumstances (2 Kings 5:17-18).

questions.question: Based on Gehazi's actions and punishment, what biblical principle about honesty and temptation can we learn?
options: Temptation can be resisted by integrity
Taking gifts secretly is acceptable for servants
Dishonesty goes unpunished if done quietly
Spiritual leaders should accept gifts for their work
questions.correctAnswer: Temptation can be resisted by integrity
questions.explanation: Gehazi's deceit in taking gifts led to his punishment with leprosy (2 Kings 5:20-27). This teaches the importance of resisting temptation and maintaining honesty in all circumstances, especially in service to God (2 Kings 5:25-27).

questions.question: How does the king of Israel's reaction to Naaman's letter show the importance of trusting God's sovereignty in difficult situations?
options: The king trusted God immediately
The king doubted God's power and was distressed
The king ignored the letter
The king sent his own army
questions.correctAnswer: The king doubted God's power and was distressed
questions.explanation: The king tore his clothes in despair, doubting that God would heal Naaman (2 Kings 5:7). This shows that even leaders can struggle with trusting God's sovereignty, but through Elisha, God demonstrated His power (2 Kings 5:8-10).

questions.question: True or False: Naaman's healing came because he demanded a sign from Elisha before obeying.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Naaman was initially angry because Elisha did not come out or perform a sign, but he obeyed by washing in the Jordan and was healed (2 Kings 5:11-14). His healing was due to obedience, not demanding signs.

questions.question: True or False: Gehazi was honest about his actions when confronted by Elisha.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Gehazi lied, claiming he went nowhere when Elisha asked, demonstrating lack of honesty and integrity (2 Kings 5:25).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and reluctance to obey simple commands from God. Based on Naaman’s story, which biblical truth would you share?
options: God rewards only grand gestures
Obedience to God’s instructions, even if simple, leads to blessing
Waiting for signs is necessary before obeying
Pride is acceptable if you have status
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s instructions, even if simple, leads to blessing
questions.explanation: Naaman's healing came after he humbled himself to obey the simple directive to wash seven times, teaching that humble obedience brings God's blessing (2 Kings 5:10-14).

questions.question: How does the story of the Israelite maid encourage us about the power of witnessing and faith in daily life?
options: Witnessing is only for clergy
Faithful testimony can impact people even in difficult situations
Only miracles convince unbelievers
Faith is private and not shared
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful testimony can impact people even in difficult situations
questions.explanation: The maid’s faith and testimony to Naaman’s wife led to Naaman seeking healing, illustrating how personal witness can have powerful effects (2 Kings 5:2-3).

questions.question: What lesson about contentment and gratitude can be learned from Elisha's refusal of Naaman's gifts?
options: Gratitude is shown by accepting gifts
Contentment protects from greed and maintains spiritual focus
Leaders should always accept gifts
Wealth is a sign of God's blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Contentment protects from greed and maintains spiritual focus
questions.explanation: Elisha refused Naaman’s gifts to maintain spiritual integrity and show contentment with God's provision (2 Kings 5:15-16), teaching believers to be content and avoid greed.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Naaman asked for two mule burdens of ______ so he could worship the LORD in Syria.
options: gold
earth
silver
water
questions.correctAnswer: earth
questions.explanation: Naaman requested earth to offer sacrifices to God in a foreign land, emphasizing the importance of worship and devotion wherever we are (2 Kings 5:17).

questions.question: What does Gehazi's punishment teach about the consequences of dishonesty in Christian service?
options: Dishonesty goes unnoticed
Dishonesty can bring severe consequences
Dishonesty is sometimes necessary
Only leaders face consequences for dishonesty
questions.correctAnswer: Dishonesty can bring severe consequences
questions.explanation: Gehazi was struck with leprosy as a direct consequence of his deceit, showing that dishonesty is serious and punished by God (2 Kings 5:26-27).

questions.question: How does Naaman’s story teach us about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing?
options: Naaman gave up quickly when not healed immediately
Naaman persisted and obeyed despite initial anger
Naaman demanded immediate healing without obeying
Naaman sought other gods for healing
questions.correctAnswer: Naaman persisted and obeyed despite initial anger
questions.explanation: Though initially angry, Naaman listened to his servants and obeyed Elisha’s instructions, showing perseverance and trust in God’s method and timing (2 Kings 5:12-14).

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 5.

questions.question: What role did Naaman hold that demonstrated his importance in the Syrian army?
options: Captain of the host of the king of Syria
King of Syria
Chief prophet of Syria
High priest of Damascus
questions.correctAnswer: Captain of the host of the king of Syria
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:1 describes Naaman as the captain of the host of the king of Syria, highlighting his military leadership and esteemed position.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 5, who informed Naaman's wife about the prophet in Samaria who could heal Naaman?
options: A little maid taken captive from Israel
Elisha himself
The king of Israel
Naaman’s servants
questions.correctAnswer: A little maid taken captive from Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:2-3 explains that a little maid from Israel, taken captive by the Syrians, told Naaman's wife about the prophet who could heal Naaman’s leprosy.

questions.question: How did the king of Israel initially react when he received the letter from the king of Syria about healing Naaman?
options: He tore his clothes in distress
He sent an army to Syria
He ordered Naaman to be imprisoned
He immediately sent Elisha to heal Naaman
questions.correctAnswer: He tore his clothes in distress
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:7 states that the king of Israel rent his clothes upon reading the letter, feeling accused unfairly and overwhelmed by the request to heal Naaman.

questions.question: What was Elisha's response to the king of Israel's distress over Naaman's letter?
options: He invited Naaman to come to him for healing
He ignored the king's letter
He requested silver and gold to heal Naaman
He sent a message to the king of Syria
questions.correctAnswer: He invited Naaman to come to him for healing
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 5:8, Elisha instructs the king of Israel to let Naaman come to him so he will know there is a prophet in Israel.

questions.question: What instruction did Elisha give to Naaman for his healing?
options: Wash seven times in the Jordan River
Offer a burnt sacrifice
Fast for seven days
Pray at the temple of Rimmon
questions.correctAnswer: Wash seven times in the Jordan River
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:10 records Elisha's instruction to Naaman to wash seven times in the Jordan River to be healed of his leprosy.

questions.question: Why was Naaman initially angry and offended by Elisha’s instruction?
options: He expected Elisha to perform a dramatic healing himself
He did not believe in the God of Israel
He was afraid of the Jordan River
He wanted to pay Elisha for the healing
questions.correctAnswer: He expected Elisha to perform a dramatic healing himself
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:11 shows Naaman’s anger because he expected Elisha to come out, call on God, and perform a conspicuous healing act rather than a simple washing.

questions.question: Naaman questioned why he should wash in the Jordan River instead of which rivers of Damascus?
options: Abana and Pharpar
Euphrates and Tigris
Nile and Jordan
Gihon and Pishon
questions.correctAnswer: Abana and Pharpar
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:12 records Naaman’s preference for the rivers Abana and Pharpar of Damascus, which he considered superior to the waters of Israel.

questions.question: What convinced Naaman to follow Elisha’s instructions and wash in the Jordan?
options: His servants persuaded him
He received a new vision
The king of Syria commanded him
He saw a sign in the sky
questions.correctAnswer: His servants persuaded him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:13 shows that Naaman's servants reasoned with him, encouraging obedience to the prophet’s simple command, which led to his eventual healing.

questions.question: What was the result after Naaman washed seven times in the Jordan as instructed?
options: His flesh was restored like that of a little child
He remained a leper
He gained strength but not healing
He was struck down by a curse
questions.correctAnswer: His flesh was restored like that of a little child
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:14 explains that after washing in the Jordan seven times, Naaman’s flesh was restored and he was completely clean.

questions.question: What theological confession did Naaman make after his healing?
options: There is no God in all the earth but in Israel
Baal is the true God of the nations
The gods of Damascus are more powerful
He would worship Rimmon only
questions.correctAnswer: There is no God in all the earth but in Israel
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 5:15, Naaman acknowledges the uniqueness of the God of Israel after experiencing His power firsthand.

questions.question: How did Elisha respond when Naaman offered him a gift after his healing?
options: He refused to accept any gifts
He accepted a large portion of the silver
He asked for a mule's burden of earth
He requested a burnt offering
questions.correctAnswer: He refused to accept any gifts
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:16 shows Elisha’s refusal to accept any gifts from Naaman, emphasizing that the healing was a gift from God, not a transaction.

questions.question: Naaman requested two mules' burden of earth from Elisha. What was the purpose of this request?
options: To offer sacrifices to the LORD on Syrian soil
To build a monument for Elisha
To carry the earth back to Israel
To plant crops in his homeland
questions.correctAnswer: To offer sacrifices to the LORD on Syrian soil
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:17 states Naaman asked for earth so he could offer burnt offerings to the LORD while in Syria, acknowledging the LORD’s sovereignty beyond Israel.

questions.question: What was Gehazi's motivation for pursuing Naaman after he left Elisha?
options: To deceitfully obtain gifts from Naaman
To bring Naaman back to Elisha
To ask Naaman for healing himself
To warn Naaman against idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: To deceitfully obtain gifts from Naaman
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:20 reveals Gehazi’s plan to chase after Naaman to take some of the gifts that Elisha had refused.

questions.question: What punishment did Elisha pronounce on Gehazi for his greed and deception?
options: He was struck with Naaman’s leprosy
He was exiled from Israel
He lost his position as servant
He was imprisoned by the king
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck with Naaman’s leprosy
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 5:27 states that Gehazi was cursed with Naaman’s leprosy as punishment for his greed and deceit.

questions.question: True or False: Naaman’s initial refusal to wash in the Jordan River reflects a common cultural bias in the ancient Near East against foreign rivers compared to local waters.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Naaman’s preference for the rivers Abana and Pharpar (2 Kings 5:12) shows a cultural pride and bias toward local waters rather than the foreign Jordan, reflecting historical attitudes toward sacred geography.

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Naaman's healing from leprosy in 2 Kings 5 primarily demonstrate about God's power and authority?
options: God alone has authority to heal and give life
Healing comes only through physical remedies
Kings have power over life and death
Prophets cannot effect healing
questions.correctAnswer: God alone has authority to heal and give life
questions.explanation: Naaman's healing shows God's unique authority over life, as the king of Israel lamented he was not God to heal (2 Kings 5:7). This aligns with Scripture such as Deuteronomy 32:39, Exodus 15:26, John 5:21, and Revelation 21:4 emphasizing God's power to heal and give life.

questions.question: How does Naaman’s initial reaction to Elisha’s instructions reveal a common human struggle addressed in theology?
options: Resistance to simple obedience and faith
Immediate acceptance of God's word
Rejection of all prophets
Demanding visible miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Resistance to simple obedience and faith
questions.explanation: Naaman’s anger and refusal to wash in the Jordan show a struggle to trust God's simple means, illustrating human pride and doubt (2 Kings 5:11-12). This reflects broader theological themes of faith and obedience seen in Hebrews 11:6, Proverbs 3:5-6, James 2:17, and Romans 1:17.

questions.question: What theological truth is conveyed by Elisha’s refusal to accept Naaman’s gift after healing him?
options: God’s grace is a gift, not a transaction
Healing must be purchased
Prophets always accept gifts
God’s blessings are earned by wealth
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace is a gift, not a transaction
questions.explanation: Elisha’s refusal (2 Kings 5:16) highlights that salvation and healing are unmerited gifts of God’s grace, not bought by money, consistent with Ephesians 2:8-9, Romans 6:23, Isaiah 55:1, and Titus 3:5.

questions.question: What doctrinal significance does Naaman’s confession, 'now I know that there is no God in all the earth but in Israel,' hold?
options: Affirmation of monotheism and YHWH's uniqueness
Acknowledgment of many gods
Recognition of Syrian gods' superiority
Denial of God’s sovereignty
questions.correctAnswer: Affirmation of monotheism and YHWH's uniqueness
questions.explanation: Naaman’s confession (2 Kings 5:15) confirms the doctrine of the one true God, consistent with Deuteronomy 6:4, Isaiah 45:5, John 17:3, and 1 Corinthians 8:6, affirming God’s exclusive deity.

questions.question: How does Gehazi’s sin and subsequent punishment illustrate a theological principle regarding sin and holiness?
options: Sin separates from God's holiness and brings judgment
Sin has no consequences
Greed is acceptable for God’s servants
God ignores secret sins
questions.correctAnswer: Sin separates from God's holiness and brings judgment
questions.explanation: Gehazi’s greed and deceit lead to him receiving Naaman’s leprosy (2 Kings 5:27), illustrating that sin breaks fellowship with God and results in judgment, consistent with Isaiah 59:2, Romans 6:23, Hebrews 12:6, and 1 John 1:6-7.

questions.question: What does Naaman’s request for two mule-loads of earth to take back to Syria signify about his understanding of worship and the presence of God?
options: God’s presence is tied to the land of Israel
God can be worshiped anywhere equally
Worship is irrelevant to the land
Earth has magical power
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence is tied to the land of Israel
questions.explanation: Naaman’s request (2 Kings 5:17) reflects early acknowledgment that YHWH’s presence is localized with Israel’s land, consistent with biblical theology of sacred space (Exodus 3:12, Psalm 132:13, Deuteronomy 12:5, and Ezekiel 37:21-22).

questions.question: What theological insight can be derived from Naaman’s concern about bowing in the house of Rimmon while serving the LORD?
options: Conflict between faithfulness to God and social pressures
Idolatry is acceptable if secret
Worship of other gods is permitted
No tension exists in worship practices
questions.correctAnswer: Conflict between faithfulness to God and social pressures
questions.explanation: Naaman’s plea for pardon (2 Kings 5:18) reveals the tension believers face between societal obligations and exclusive worship of God, reflecting biblical calls to faithfulness under persecution (Daniel 3:16-18, Exodus 20:3, 1 Corinthians 10:21, and Revelation 2:10).

questions.question: Why did the king of Israel tear his clothes upon receiving the letter from the king of Syria?
options: He felt accused unjustly and doubted his ability to heal
He was joyful about the request
He wanted to send a gift immediately
He planned to wage war
questions.correctAnswer: He felt accused unjustly and doubted his ability to heal
questions.explanation: The king tore his clothes (2 Kings 5:7) because he was distressed at being seen as God and accused of failing to heal, underscoring human limitations contrasted with divine sovereignty, as echoed in Exodus 33:20, Psalm 115:3, Isaiah 40:28, and Romans 9:20.

questions.question: What does Elisha’s instruction to Naaman to wash in the Jordan seven times teach about the nature of God's commands and human response?
options: God’s commands may appear simple but require humble obedience
God demands complicated rituals
Human effort alone effects healing
Prophets perform miracles by themselves
questions.correctAnswer: God’s commands may appear simple but require humble obedience
questions.explanation: Elisha’s command (2 Kings 5:10) is simple but tests Naaman’s humility and faith, illustrating that God’s work often requires obedience beyond human expectation, consistent with Micah 6:8, 1 Samuel 15:22, Isaiah 1:19, and James 1:22.

questions.question: How does the role of the Israelite maid in Naaman’s healing narrative emphasize God’s providence and use of the lowly?
options: God uses the humble and lowly to fulfill His purposes
Only kings can deliver healing
Prophets ignore common people
Healing comes through warriors
questions.correctAnswer: God uses the humble and lowly to fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: The maid’s knowledge (2 Kings 5:2-3) shows God’s providential use of a captive servant to reveal His prophet's power, echoing themes in 1 Samuel 16:7, Luke 1:48, James 2:5, and Matthew 11:25 about God exalting the humble.

questions.question: What doctrinal lesson about God’s sovereignty is emphasized by Naaman’s healing happening through the prophet Elisha and not directly by the king or earthly powers?
options: God sovereignly works through His appointed servants
Kings hold ultimate spiritual power
Healing is independent of God’s will
Prophets have no role in salvation
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly works through His appointed servants
questions.explanation: Elisha’s role (2 Kings 5:8-9) demonstrates God's sovereign choice to act through prophets, affirming divine mediation as in Exodus 3:1-12, Numbers 12:6, Hebrews 1:1-2, and 1 Peter 1:10-12.

questions.question: How does the episode of Naaman’s healing affirm the doctrine of salvation by grace through faith rather than works?
options: Naaman was healed by faith in God’s word, not by his own merit
Naaman earned healing through his valor
Healing was due to his wealth
Naaman’s status brought automatic healing
questions.correctAnswer: Naaman was healed by faith in God’s word, not by his own merit
questions.explanation: Naaman’s obedience to Elisha’s instructions (2 Kings 5:14) shows salvation as a gift received by faith, paralleling Ephesians 2:8-9, Romans 4:5, Galatians 2:16, and Hebrews 11:6.

questions.question: What does the story of Naaman and Gehazi teach about the holiness of God and the seriousness of sin among God’s servants?
options: God demands holiness and punishes sin even in His servants
Servants of God are exempt from judgment
Sin is overlooked in ministry
Only laypeople face consequences for sin
questions.correctAnswer: God demands holiness and punishes sin even in His servants
questions.explanation: Gehazi’s punishment (2 Kings 5:26-27) teaches that God’s holiness requires all to be accountable, consistent with Leviticus 10:3, 1 Samuel 2:30, Hebrews 12:10, and James 3:1.

questions.question: Why is Naaman’s cleansing in the Jordan River significant in biblical theology?
options: It symbolizes spiritual cleansing and new life
It was a common ritual with no meaning
It shows reliance on foreign waters
It was purely a physical act
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes spiritual cleansing and new life
questions.explanation: Naaman’s washing (2 Kings 5:14) anticipates biblical themes of baptism and spiritual renewal, as in Ezekiel 36:25-27, Psalm 51:7, Acts 22:16, and Titus 3:5.

questions.question: What apologetic argument does Naaman’s healing narrative provide against the claim that God is limited to a single nation or people?
options: God’s grace extends beyond Israel to Gentiles
Only Israelites receive God’s grace
God ignores foreigners
Non-Israelites cannot believe
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace extends beyond Israel to Gentiles
questions.explanation: Naaman, a Syrian, is healed by Israel’s God (2 Kings 5:1-15), illustrating God’s universal grace, supported by Genesis 12:3, Isaiah 49:6, Acts 10:34-35, and Romans 15:9.
